title.en: Biographies of Laozi and Han Fei
title.raw: 《老子韓非列傳》 Biographies of Laozi and Han Fei

sentences.zh: 老子者，楚苦縣厲鄉曲仁里人也，姓李氏，名耳，字耼，周守藏室之史也。

translations.literal: Laozi was a man of Qu Ren Village, Li Township, Ku County, Chu, surname Li, name Er, courtesy name Dan, Zhou's keeper of the archives.
translations.idiomatic: Laozi was a man of Quren Village in Li Township, Ku County, Chu. His surname was Li, personal name Er, courtesy name Dan. He was the Zhou court's keeper of the archives.

translations.literal: Laozi was a man of Qu Ren Village, Li Township, Ku County, Chu, surname Li, name Er, courtesy name Dan, Zhou's keeper of the archives.

sentences.zh: 孔子適周，將問禮於老子。

translations.literal: Confucius went to Zhou, about to ask about rites from Laozi.
translations.idiomatic: Confucius went to Zhou, intending to ask Laozi about rites.

sentences.zh: 老子曰：「子所言者，其人與骨皆已朽矣，獨其言在耳。

translations.literal: Laozi said: 'What you speak of, their persons and bones have all rotted away, only their words remain.
translations.idiomatic: Laozi said: 'What you speak of—their persons and bones have all rotted away. Only their words remain.

sentences.zh: 且君子得其時則駕，不得其時則蓬累而行。

translations.literal: Moreover gentlemen getting their time then drive, not getting their time then roll along like tumbleweed.
translations.idiomatic: Moreover, gentlemen who get their time then drive; those who do not get their time roll along like tumbleweed.

sentences.zh: 吾聞之，良賈深藏若虛，君子盛德容貌若愚。

translations.literal: I have heard that good merchants deeply hide as if empty, gentlemen of great virtue appear foolish in countenance.
translations.idiomatic: I have heard that good merchants deeply conceal their wares as if empty, and gentlemen of great virtue appear foolish in countenance.

sentences.zh: 去子之驕氣與多欲，態色與淫志，是皆無益於子之身。

translations.literal: Rid yourself of arrogant airs and many desires, affected expressions and licentious ambitions, these are all of no benefit to your person.
translations.idiomatic: Rid yourself of arrogant airs and many desires, affected expressions and licentious ambitions—these are all of no benefit to your person.

sentences.zh: 吾所以告子，若是而已。」

translations.literal: What I tell you is only this.'
translations.idiomatic: What I tell you is only this.''

sentences.zh: 孔子去，謂弟子曰：「鳥，吾知其能飛；

translations.literal: Confucius left, told his disciples: 'Birds, I know they can fly;
translations.idiomatic: Confucius left and told his disciples: 'Birds—I know they can fly;

sentences.zh: 魚，吾知其能游；

translations.literal: fish, I know they can swim;
translations.idiomatic: fish—I know they can swim;

sentences.zh: 獸，吾知其能走。

translations.literal: beasts, I know they can run.
translations.idiomatic: beasts—I know they can run.

sentences.zh: 走者可以為罔，游者可以為綸，飛者可以為矰。

translations.literal: Runners can be netted, swimmers can be lined, flyers can be arrowed.
translations.idiomatic: Runners can be netted, swimmers can be lined, flyers can be arrowed.

sentences.zh: 至於龍，吾不能知其乘風雲而上天。

translations.literal: As for dragons, I cannot know how they ride wind and clouds up to heaven.
translations.idiomatic: As for dragons—I cannot know how they ride wind and clouds up to heaven.

sentences.zh: 吾今日見老子，其猶龍邪！」

translations.literal: I today saw Laozi, it was like a dragon!'
translations.idiomatic: I today saw Laozi—it was like a dragon!''

translations.literal: Confucius went to Zhou, about to ask about rites from Laozi. Laozi said: 'What you speak of, their persons and bones have all rotted away, only their words remain. Moreover gentlemen getting their time then drive, not getting their time then roll along like tumbleweed. I have heard that good merchants deeply hide as if empty, gentlemen of great virtue appear foolish in countenance. Rid yourself of arrogant airs and many desires, affected expressions and licentious ambitions, these are all of no benefit to your person. What I tell you is only this.' Confucius left, told his disciples: 'Birds, I know they can fly; fish, I know they can swim; beasts, I know they can run. Runners can be netted, swimmers can be lined, flyers can be arrowed. As for dragons, I cannot know how they ride wind and clouds up to heaven. I today saw Laozi, it was like a dragon!'

sentences.zh: 老子修道德，其學以自隱無名為務。

translations.literal: Laozi cultivated morality and virtue, his learning took self-concealment and namelessness as its purpose.
translations.idiomatic: Laozi cultivated the Way and virtue. His learning took self-concealment and namelessness as its purpose.

sentences.zh: 居周久之，見周之衰，乃遂去。

translations.literal: Stayed in Zhou for a long time, seeing Zhou's decline, then departed.
translations.idiomatic: He stayed in Zhou for a long time. Seeing Zhou's decline, he then departed.

sentences.zh: 至關，關令尹喜曰：「子將隱矣，彊為我著書。」

translations.literal: Arrived at the pass, the pass commander Yin Xi said: 'You will hide yourself, force yourself to write a book for me.'
translations.idiomatic: When he arrived at the pass, the pass commander Yin Xi said: 'You will conceal yourself—force yourself to write a book for me.'

sentences.zh: 於是老子乃著書上下篇，言道德之意五千餘言而去，莫知其所終。

translations.literal: Thus Laozi wrote a book in upper and lower chapters, speaking of the meaning of morality and virtue in over five thousand words and departed, none know where he ended.
translations.idiomatic: Thus Laozi wrote a book in upper and lower chapters, speaking of the meaning of the Way and virtue in over five thousand words, and departed. None know where he ended.

translations.literal: Laozi cultivated morality and virtue, his learning took self-concealment and namelessness as its purpose. Stayed in Zhou for a long time, seeing Zhou's decline, then departed. Arrived at the pass, the pass commander Yin Xi said: 'You will hide yourself, force yourself to write a book for me.' Thus Laozi wrote a book in upper and lower chapters, speaking of the meaning of morality and virtue in over five thousand words and departed, none know where he ended.

sentences.zh: 或曰：老萊子亦楚人也，著書十五篇，言道家之用，與孔子同時云。

translations.literal: Some say: Lao Lai Zi was also a Chu man, wrote fifteen chapters, speaking of Daoist applications, contemporary with Confucius.
translations.idiomatic: Some say: Lao Lai Zi was also a Chu man. He wrote fifteen chapters speaking of Daoist applications, and was contemporary with Confucius.

translations.literal: Some say: Lao Lai Zi was also a Chu man, wrote fifteen chapters, speaking of Daoist applications, contemporary with Confucius.

sentences.zh: 蓋老子百有六十餘歲，或言二百餘歲，以其修道而養壽也。

translations.literal: Laozi was over one hundred sixty years old, some say over two hundred years, because he cultivated the Dao and nurtured longevity.
translations.idiomatic: Laozi was over one hundred sixty years old, some say over two hundred years, because he cultivated the Dao and nurtured longevity.

translations.literal: Laozi was over one hundred sixty years old, some say over two hundred years, because he cultivated the Dao and nurtured longevity.

sentences.zh: 自孔子死之後百二十九年，而史記周太史儋見秦獻公曰：「始秦與周合，合五百歲而離，離七十歲而霸王者出焉。」

translations.literal: After Confucius died 129 years, and the records say Zhou Grand Historian Tan saw Qin Lord Xian saying: 'Originally Qin and Zhou united, united five hundred years and separated, separated seventy years and a hegemon-king will emerge.'
translations.idiomatic: 129 years after Confucius died, the records say Zhou Grand Historian Tan saw Qin Lord Xian and said: 'Originally Qin and Zhou were united. United for five hundred years they separated. Separated seventy years and a hegemon-king will emerge.'

sentences.zh: 或曰儋即老子，或曰非也，世莫知其然否。

translations.literal: Some say Tan was Laozi, some say not, the world does not know if it was so or not.
translations.idiomatic: Some say Tan was Laozi, some say he was not. The world does not know if it was so or not.

sentences.zh: 老子，隱君子也。

translations.literal: Laozi was a concealed gentleman.
translations.idiomatic: Laozi was a concealed gentleman.

translations.literal: After Confucius died 129 years, and the records say Zhou Grand Historian Tan saw Qin Lord Xian saying: 'Originally Qin and Zhou united, united five hundred years and separated, separated seventy years and a hegemon-king will emerge.' Some say Tan was Laozi, some say not, the world does not know if it was so or not. Laozi was a concealed gentleman.

sentences.zh: 老子之子名宗，宗為魏將，封於段干。

translations.literal: Laozi's son named Zong, Zong was Wei general, enfeoffed at Duan Gan.
translations.idiomatic: Laozi's son was named Zong. Zong was a Wei general and was enfeoffed at Duan Gan.

sentences.zh: 宗子注，注子宮，宮玄孫假，假仕於漢孝文帝。

translations.literal: Zong's son Zhu, Zhu's son Gong, Gong's great-grandson Jia, Jia served Han Xiaowen Emperor.
translations.idiomatic: Zong's son was Zhu. Zhu's son was Gong. Gong's great-grandson was Jia. Jia served Han Emperor Xiaowen.

sentences.zh: 而假之子解為膠西王卬太傅，因家于齊焉。

translations.literal: Jia's son Xie was Jiaoxi King Ang's tutor, thus established household in Qi.
translations.idiomatic: Jia's son Xie was tutor to Jiaoxi King Ang, thus establishing a household in Qi.

translations.literal: Laozi's son named Zong, Zong was Wei general, enfeoffed at Duan Gan. Zong's son Zhu, Zhu's son Gong, Gong's great-grandson Jia, Jia served Han Xiaowen Emperor. Jia's son Xie was Jiaoxi King Ang's tutor, thus established household in Qi.

sentences.zh: 世之學老子者則絀儒學，儒學亦絀老子。

translations.literal: Those in the world who study Laozi then belittle Confucian learning, Confucian learning also belittles Laozi.
translations.idiomatic: Those in the world who study Laozi then belittle Confucian learning. Confucian learning also belittles Laozi.

sentences.zh: 「道不同不相為謀」，豈謂是邪？

translations.literal: 'Ways different do not plan for each other', is this what is meant?
translations.idiomatic: 'Ways different do not plan for each other'—is this what is meant?

sentences.zh: 李耳無為自化，清靜自正。

translations.literal: Li Er non-action self-transforms, pure quiet self-corrects.
translations.idiomatic: Li Er: non-action self-transforms, pure quiet self-corrects.

translations.literal: Those in the world who study Laozi then belittle Confucian learning, Confucian learning also belittles Laozi. 'Ways different do not plan for each other', is this what is meant? Li Er non-action self-transforms, pure quiet self-corrects.

sentences.zh: 莊子者，蒙人也，名周。

translations.literal: Zhuangzi was a Meng man, named Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: Zhuangzi was a man of Meng, named Zhou.

sentences.zh: 周嘗為蒙漆園吏，與梁惠王、齊宣王同時。

translations.literal: Zhou once was Meng lacquer garden official, contemporary with Liang Hui King and Qi Xuan King.
translations.idiomatic: Zhou once served as an official in Meng's lacquer garden, and was contemporary with Liang King Hui and Qi King Xuan.

sentences.zh: 其學無所不闚，然其要本歸於老子之言。

translations.literal: His learning overlooked nothing, yet its essentials fundamentally returned to Laozi's words.
translations.idiomatic: His learning overlooked nothing, yet its essentials fundamentally returned to Laozi's words.

sentences.zh: 故其著書十餘萬言，大抵率寓言也。

translations.literal: Thus his written books over one hundred thousand words, for the most part allegorical tales.
translations.idiomatic: Thus his written books were over one hundred thousand words, for the most part allegorical tales.

sentences.zh: 作漁父、盜跖、胠篋，以詆訿孔子之徒，以明老子之術。

translations.literal: Made Fisherman, Robber Zhi, Cutting Open Boxes, to mock and ridicule Confucius's followers, to clarify Laozi's techniques.
translations.idiomatic: He wrote 'The Fisherman,' 'Robber Zhi,' and 'Cutting Open Boxes' to mock and ridicule Confucius's followers and to clarify Laozi's techniques.

sentences.zh: 畏累虛、亢桑子之屬，皆空語無事實。

translations.literal: Fearful Burden Void, Kang Sang Zi and the like, all empty words without actual events.
translations.idiomatic: Fearful Burden Void, Kang Sang Zi and the like—all empty words without actual events.

sentences.zh: 然善屬書離辭，指事類情，用剽剝儒、墨，雖當世宿學不能自解免也。

translations.literal: Yet good at connecting books and separating phrases, pointing to affairs and analogizing feelings, using to strip Confucians and Mohists, even contemporary veteran scholars could not exempt themselves.
translations.idiomatic: Yet he was good at connecting books and separating phrases, pointing to affairs and analogizing feelings, using this to strip Confucians and Mohists—even contemporary veteran scholars could not exempt themselves.

sentences.zh: 其言洸洋自恣以適己，故自王公大人不能器之。

translations.literal: His words vast and unrestrained to suit himself, therefore even kings and great men could not value him.
translations.idiomatic: His words were vast and unrestrained to suit himself, therefore even kings and great men could not value him.

translations.literal: Zhuangzi was a Meng man, named Zhou. Zhou once was Meng lacquer garden official, contemporary with Liang Hui King and Qi Xuan King. His learning overlooked nothing, yet its essentials fundamentally returned to Laozi's words. Thus his written books over one hundred thousand words, for the most part allegorical tales. Made Fisherman, Robber Zhi, Cutting Open Boxes, to mock and ridicule Confucius's followers, to clarify Laozi's techniques. Fearful Burden Void, Kang Sang Zi and the like, all empty words without actual events. Yet good at connecting books and separating phrases, pointing to affairs and analogizing feelings, using to strip Confucians and Mohists, even contemporary veteran scholars could not exempt themselves. His words vast and unrestrained to suit himself, therefore even kings and great men could not value him.

sentences.zh: 楚威王聞莊周賢，使使厚幣迎之，許以為相。

translations.literal: Chu Wei King heard Zhuang Zhou was worthy, sent envoys with rich gifts to welcome him, promised to make him prime minister.
translations.idiomatic: Chu King Wei heard that Zhuang Zhou was worthy and sent envoys with rich gifts to welcome him, promising to make him prime minister.

sentences.zh: 莊周笑謂楚使者曰：「千金，重利；

translations.literal: Zhuang Zhou laughing told Chu envoy: 'Thousand gold, heavy profit;
translations.idiomatic: Zhuang Zhou laughing told the Chu envoy: 'Thousand pieces of gold is heavy profit;

sentences.zh: 卿相，尊位也。

translations.literal: prime minister, honored position.
translations.idiomatic: prime minister is an honored position.

sentences.zh: 子獨不見郊祭之犧牛乎？

translations.literal: You alone have not seen the suburban sacrifice's sacrificial ox?
translations.idiomatic: Have you alone not seen the sacrificial ox for the suburban sacrifice?

sentences.zh: 養食之數歲，衣以文繡，以入大廟。

translations.literal: Raised and fed several years, clothed in embroidered patterns, to enter the great temple.
translations.idiomatic: It is raised and fed for several years, clothed in embroidered patterns, and led to enter the great temple.

sentences.zh: 當是之時，雖欲為孤豚，豈可得乎？

translations.literal: At that time, though wishing to be a lone piglet, how could it be obtained?
translations.idiomatic: At that time, though it wished to be a lone piglet, how could that be obtained?

sentences.zh: 子亟去，無污我。

translations.literal: You quickly go, do not defile me.
translations.idiomatic: You quickly go—do not defile me.

sentences.zh: 我寧游戲污瀆之中自快，無為有國者所羈，終身不仕，以快吾志焉。」

translations.literal: I would rather frolic in mud and filth to please myself, not be restrained by rulers of states, lifelong not serve, to delight my ambitions.'
translations.idiomatic: I would rather frolic in mud and filth to please myself, not be restrained by rulers of states, and lifelong not serve—to delight my ambitions.''

translations.literal: Chu Wei King heard Zhuang Zhou was worthy, sent envoys with rich gifts to welcome him, promised to make him prime minister. Zhuang Zhou laughing told Chu envoy: 'Thousand gold, heavy profit; prime minister, honored position. You alone have not seen the suburban sacrifice's sacrificial ox? Raised and fed several years, clothed in embroidered patterns, to enter the great temple. At that time, though wishing to be a lone piglet, how could it be obtained? You quickly go, do not defile me. I would rather frolic in mud and filth to please myself, not be restrained by rulers of states, lifelong not serve, to delight my ambitions.'

sentences.zh: 申不害者，京人也，故鄭之賤臣。

translations.literal: Shen Buhai was a Jing man, formerly Zheng's humble minister.
translations.idiomatic: Shen Buhai was a man of Jing, formerly a humble minister of Zheng.

sentences.zh: 學術以干韓昭侯，昭侯用為相。

translations.literal: Used learning and technique to petition Han Zhao Hou, Zhao Hou employed him as prime minister.
translations.idiomatic: He used his learning and techniques to petition Han Lord Zhao, and Lord Zhao employed him as prime minister.

sentences.zh: 內修政教，外應諸侯，十五年。

translations.literal: Within repaired governance and teaching, without responded to feudal lords, fifteen years.
translations.idiomatic: Within he repaired governance and teaching; without he responded to the feudal lords—for fifteen years.

sentences.zh: 終申子之身，國治兵彊，無侵韓者。

translations.literal: Throughout Shen Zi's lifetime, state orderly troops strong, none invaded Han.
translations.idiomatic: Throughout Shen Buhai's lifetime, the state was orderly and the troops strong—none invaded Han.

sentences.zh: 申子之學本於黃老而主刑名。

translations.literal: Shen Zi's learning based on Huang Lao yet emphasized punishment and name.
translations.idiomatic: Shen Buhai's learning was based on Huang Lao yet emphasized punishment and name.

sentences.zh: 著書二篇，號曰申子。

translations.literal: Wrote books in two chapters, called Shen Zi.
translations.idiomatic: He wrote books in two chapters, called the Shen Zi.

translations.literal: Shen Buhai was a Jing man, formerly Zheng's humble minister. Used learning and technique to petition Han Zhao Hou, Zhao Hou employed him as prime minister. Within repaired governance and teaching, without responded to feudal lords, fifteen years. Throughout Shen Zi's lifetime, state orderly troops strong, none invaded Han. Shen Zi's learning based on Huang Lao yet emphasized punishment and name. Wrote books in two chapters, called Shen Zi.

sentences.zh: 韓非者，韓之諸公子也。

translations.literal: Han Fei was one of Han's various princes.
translations.idiomatic: Han Fei was one of Han's various princes.

sentences.zh: 喜刑名法術之學，而其歸本於黃老。

translations.literal: Delighted in punishment-name law-technique learning, yet his foundation returned to Huang Lao.
translations.idiomatic: He delighted in the learning of punishment, name, law, and technique, yet his foundation returned to Huang Lao.

sentences.zh: 非為人口吃，不能道說，而善著書。

translations.literal: Fei had a stutter, could not speak fluently, yet was good at writing books.
translations.idiomatic: Fei had a stutter and could not speak fluently, yet he was good at writing books.

sentences.zh: 與李斯俱事荀卿，斯自以為不如非。

translations.literal: Together with Li Si served Xun Qing, Si considered himself inferior to Fei.
translations.idiomatic: Together with Li Si he served Xun Qing, and Li Si considered himself inferior to Fei.

translations.literal: Han Fei was one of Han's various princes. Delighted in punishment-name law-technique learning, yet his foundation returned to Huang Lao. Fei had a stutter, could not speak fluently, yet was good at writing books. Together with Li Si served Xun Qing, Si considered himself inferior to Fei.

sentences.zh: 非見韓之削弱，數以書諫韓王，韓王不能用。

translations.literal: Fei saw Han's weakening and reduction, repeatedly with writings remonstrated Han King, Han King could not use him.
translations.idiomatic: Fei saw Han's weakening and reduction, and repeatedly remonstrated with the Han king through writings, but the Han king could not employ him.

sentences.zh: 於是韓非疾治國不務修明其法制，執勢以御其臣下，富國彊兵而以求人任賢，反舉浮淫之蠹而加之於功實之上。

translations.literal: Thus Han Fei resented governing the state not striving to clarify its legal system, grasp power to control ministers below, enrich state strengthen troops yet seek others to appoint the worthy, instead raise floating licentious parasites and place them above actual merit.
translations.idiomatic: Thus Han Fei resented that governing the state did not strive to clarify its legal system, grasp power to control ministers below, enrich the state and strengthen the troops yet seek others to appoint the worthy—instead raising floating and licentious parasites and placing them above actual merit.

sentences.zh: 以為儒者用文亂法，而俠者以武犯禁。

translations.literal: Considered Confucians use writing to disorder law, while knights use martial force to violate prohibitions.
translations.idiomatic: He considered that Confucians use writing to disorder the law, while knights use martial force to violate prohibitions.

sentences.zh: 寬則寵名譽之人，急則用介胄之士。

translations.literal: Relaxed then favor men of reputation, urgent then use armored warriors.
translations.idiomatic: When relaxed they favor men of reputation; when urgent they use armored warriors.

sentences.zh: 今者所養非所用，所用非所養。

translations.literal: Now what is nurtured is not what is used, what is used is not what is nurtured.
translations.idiomatic: Now what is nurtured is not what is used; what is used is not what is nurtured.

sentences.zh: 悲廉直不容於邪枉之臣，觀往者得失之變，故作孤憤、五蠹、內外儲、說林、說難十餘萬言。

translations.literal: Pitied uprightness not tolerated by crooked ministers, observed past gains and losses changes, thus wrote Lonely Indignation, Five Parasites, Inner and Outer Stores, Forest of Sayings, Difficulty of Persuasion over one hundred thousand words.
translations.idiomatic: He pitied that uprightness was not tolerated by crooked ministers, observed the changes in past gains and losses, thus wrote 'Lonely Indignation,' 'Five Parasites,' 'Inner and Outer Stores,' 'Forest of Sayings,' and 'Difficulty of Persuasion'—over one hundred thousand words.

translations.literal: Fei saw Han's weakening and reduction, repeatedly with writings remonstrated Han King, Han King could not use him. Thus Han Fei resented governing the state not striving to clarify its legal system, grasp power to control ministers below, enrich state strengthen troops yet seek others to appoint the worthy, instead raise floating licentious parasites and place them above actual merit. Considered Confucians use writing to disorder law, while knights use martial force to violate prohibitions. Relaxed then favor men of reputation, urgent then use armored warriors. Now what is nurtured is not what is used, what is used is not what is nurtured. Pitied uprightness not tolerated by crooked ministers, observed past gains and losses changes, thus wrote Lonely Indignation, Five Parasites, Inner and Outer Stores, Forest of Sayings, Difficulty of Persuasion over one hundred thousand words.

sentences.zh: 然韓非知說之難，為說難書甚具，終死於秦，不能自脫。

translations.literal: Yet Han Fei knew persuasion's difficulty, his Difficulty of Persuasion book very complete, ultimately died in Qin, could not save himself.
translations.idiomatic: Yet Han Fei knew the difficulty of persuasion, and his book 'Difficulty of Persuasion' was very complete—ultimately he died in Qin and could not save himself.

translations.literal: Yet Han Fei knew persuasion's difficulty, his Difficulty of Persuasion book very complete, ultimately died in Qin, could not save himself.

sentences.zh: 說難曰：

translations.literal: Difficulty of Persuasion says:
translations.idiomatic: 'Difficulty of Persuasion' says:

translations.literal: Difficulty of Persuasion says:

sentences.zh: 凡說之難，非吾知之有以說之難也；

translations.literal: The difficulty of all persuasion is not that my knowledge has difficulty in what to persuade;
translations.idiomatic: The difficulty of all persuasion is not that my knowledge has difficulty in what to persuade;

sentences.zh: 又非吾辯之難能明吾意之難也；

translations.literal: also not that my eloquence has difficulty in clarifying my intent;
translations.idiomatic: also not that my eloquence has difficulty in clarifying my intent;

sentences.zh: 又非吾敢橫失能盡之難也。

translations.literal: also not that my courage has difficulty in thoroughly exhausting it.
translations.idiomatic: also not that my courage has difficulty in thoroughly exhausting it.

sentences.zh: 凡說之難，在知所說之心，可以吾說當之。

translations.literal: The difficulty of all persuasion lies in knowing the persuaded one's heart, so my persuasion can match it.
translations.idiomatic: The difficulty of all persuasion lies in knowing the persuaded one's heart, so that my persuasion can match it.

translations.literal: The difficulty of all persuasion is not that my knowledge has difficulty in what to persuade; also not that my eloquence has difficulty in clarifying my intent; also not that my courage has difficulty in thoroughly exhausting it. The difficulty of all persuasion lies in knowing the persuaded one's heart, so my persuasion can match it.

sentences.zh: 所說出於為名高者也，而說之以厚利，則見下節而遇卑賤，必棄遠矣。

translations.literal: The persuaded emerges from seeking high name, yet persuade with thick profit, then seen as lowly conduct encountering humble position, certainly abandoned and distanced.
translations.idiomatic: The persuaded emerges from seeking high name, yet if you persuade him with thick profit, then he is seen as having lowly conduct encountering humble position—he will certainly abandon and distance you.

sentences.zh: 所說出於厚利者也。

translations.literal: The persuaded emerges from thick profit.
translations.idiomatic: The persuaded emerges from thick profit.

sentences.zh: 而說之以名高，則見無心而遠事情，必不收矣。

translations.literal: Yet persuade with high name, then seen as without heart and far from affairs, certainly not accepted.
translations.idiomatic: Yet if you persuade him with high name, then he is seen as without heart and far from affairs—he will certainly not accept you.

sentences.zh: 所說實為厚利而顯為名高者也，而說之以名高，則陽收其身而實疏之；

translations.literal: The persuaded in reality for thick profit yet appears as high name, yet persuade with high name, then superficially accepts his person yet in reality distances him;
translations.idiomatic: The persuaded in reality seeks thick profit yet appears to seek high name, yet if you persuade him with high name, then he superficially accepts your person yet in reality distances you;

sentences.zh: 若說之以厚利，則陰用其言而顯棄其身。

translations.literal: if persuade with thick profit, then secretly uses his words yet superficially abandons his person.
translations.idiomatic: if you persuade him with thick profit, then he secretly uses your words yet superficially abandons your person.

sentences.zh: 此之不可不知也。

translations.literal: This cannot not be known.
translations.idiomatic: This cannot not be known.

translations.literal: The persuaded emerges from seeking high name, yet persuade with thick profit, then seen as lowly conduct encountering humble position, certainly abandoned and distanced. The persuaded emerges from thick profit. Yet persuade with high name, then seen as without heart and far from affairs, certainly not accepted. The persuaded in reality for thick profit yet appears as high name, yet persuade with high name, then superficially accepts his person yet in reality distances him; if persuade with thick profit, then secretly uses his words yet superficially abandons his person. This cannot not be known.

sentences.zh: 夫事以密成，語以泄敗。

translations.literal: Affairs succeed through secrecy, words fail through leakage.
translations.idiomatic: Affairs succeed through secrecy; words fail through leakage.

sentences.zh: 未必其身泄之也，而語及其所匿之事，如是者身危。

translations.literal: Not necessarily his own person leaks it, yet words touch on affairs he conceals, like this the person is in danger.
translations.idiomatic: Not necessarily does his own person leak it, yet if words touch on affairs he conceals, like this the person is in danger.

sentences.zh: 貴人有過端，而說者明言善議以推其惡者，則身危。

translations.literal: Noble has fault beginnings, yet persuader clearly speaks good plans to push his evils, then person in danger.
translations.idiomatic: If a noble has fault beginnings, yet the persuader clearly speaks good plans to push his evils, then the person is in danger.

sentences.zh: 周澤未渥也而語極知，說行而有功則德亡，說不行而有敗則見疑，如是者身危。

translations.literal: Favor not yet abundant yet speaks extreme knowledge, persuasion succeeds and has merit then virtue lost, persuasion does not succeed and has defeat then seen as suspicious, like this person in danger.
translations.idiomatic: If favor is not yet abundant yet you speak of extreme knowledge, if persuasion succeeds and has merit then virtue is lost; if persuasion does not succeed and has defeat then you are seen as suspicious—like this the person is in danger.

sentences.zh: 夫貴人得計而欲自以為功，說者與知焉，則身危。

translations.literal: Noble obtains plan and wishes to consider it his own merit, persuader shares knowledge of it, then person in danger.
translations.idiomatic: If a noble obtains a plan and wishes to consider it his own merit, yet the persuader shares knowledge of it, then the person is in danger.

sentences.zh: 彼顯有所出事，迺自以為也故，說者與知焉，則身危。

translations.literal: He superficially has emerged affairs, actually considers them his own doing, persuader shares knowledge of it, then person in danger.
translations.idiomatic: If he superficially has emerged affairs yet actually considers them his own doing, and the persuader shares knowledge of it, then the person is in danger.

sentences.zh: 彊之以其所必不為，止之以其所不能已者，身危。

translations.literal: Force him with what he certainly will not do, stop him with what he cannot help but do, person in danger.
translations.idiomatic: If you force him with what he certainly will not do, or stop him with what he cannot help but do, the person is in danger.

sentences.zh: 故曰：與之論大人，則以為閒己；

translations.literal: Therefore said: Discuss great men with him, then considers you interfering with him;
translations.idiomatic: Therefore said: If you discuss great men with him, then he considers you interfering with him;

sentences.zh: 與之論細人，則以為粥權。

translations.literal: discuss petty men with him, then considers you selling influence.
translations.idiomatic: if you discuss petty men with him, then he considers you selling influence.

sentences.zh: 論其所愛，則以為借資；

translations.literal: Discuss what he loves, then considers you borrowing capital;
translations.idiomatic: if you discuss what he loves, then he considers you borrowing capital;

sentences.zh: 論其所憎，則以為嘗己。

translations.literal: discuss what he hates, then considers you testing him.
translations.idiomatic: if you discuss what he hates, then he considers you testing him.

sentences.zh: 徑省其辭，則不知而屈之；

translations.literal: Direct and concise words, then ignorant and bends you;
translations.idiomatic: if your words are direct and concise, then he considers you ignorant and bends you;

sentences.zh: 汎濫博文，則多而久之。

translations.literal: broad and extensive writings, then many and long of them.
translations.idiomatic: if your writings are broad and extensive, then he considers them many and prolonged.

sentences.zh: 順事陳意，則曰怯懦而不盡；

translations.literal: Compliant with affairs expressing intent, then says cowardly and not thorough;
translations.idiomatic: if you are compliant with affairs and express your intent, then he says you are cowardly and not thorough;

sentences.zh: 慮事廣肆，則曰草野而倨侮。

translations.literal: considering affairs broadly unrestrained, then says rustic and insolent.
translations.idiomatic: if you consider affairs broadly and unrestrained, then he says you are rustic and insolent.

sentences.zh: 此說之難，不可不知也。

translations.literal: This persuasion difficulty cannot not be known.
translations.idiomatic: This difficulty of persuasion cannot not be known.

translations.literal: Affairs succeed through secrecy, words fail through leakage. Not necessarily his own person leaks it, yet words touch on affairs he conceals, like this the person is in danger. Noble has fault beginnings, yet persuader clearly speaks good plans to push his evils, then person in danger. Favor not yet abundant yet speaks extreme knowledge, persuasion succeeds and has merit then virtue lost, persuasion does not succeed and has defeat then seen as suspicious, like this person in danger. Noble obtains plan and wishes to consider it his own merit, persuader shares knowledge of it, then person in danger. He superficially has emerged affairs, actually considers them his own doing, persuader shares knowledge of it, then person in danger. Force him with what he certainly will not do, stop him with what he cannot help but do, person in danger. Therefore said: Discuss great men with him, then considers you interfering with him; discuss petty men with him, then considers you selling influence. Discuss what he loves, then considers you borrowing capital; discuss what he hates, then considers you testing him. Direct and concise words, then ignorant and bends you; broad and extensive writings, then many and long of them. Compliant with affairs expressing intent, then says cowardly and not thorough; considering affairs broadly unrestrained, then says rustic and insolent. This persuasion difficulty cannot not be known.

sentences.zh: 凡說之務，在知飾所說之所敬，而滅其所醜。

translations.literal: The essentials of all persuasion lie in knowing to adorn what the persuaded respects, and extinguish what he finds ugly.
translations.idiomatic: The essentials of all persuasion lie in knowing to adorn what the persuaded respects, and extinguish what he finds ugly.

sentences.zh: 彼自知其計，則毋以其失窮之；

translations.literal: He himself knows his plans, then do not press him with his losses;
translations.idiomatic: If he himself knows his plans, then do not press him with his losses;

sentences.zh: 自勇其斷，則毋以其敵怒之；

translations.literal: He himself braves his decisions, then do not anger him with his enemies;
translations.idiomatic: If he himself braves his decisions, then do not anger him with his enemies;

sentences.zh: 自多其力，則毋以其難概之。

translations.literal: he himself boasts his strength, then do not overwhelm him with its difficulty.
translations.idiomatic: if he himself boasts his strength, then do not overwhelm him with its difficulty.

sentences.zh: 規異事與同計，譽異人與同行者，則以飾之無傷也。

translations.literal: Plan different affairs with same plan, praise different people with same travelers, then adorn them without harm.
translations.idiomatic: Plan different affairs with the same plan, praise different people with the same travelers, then adorn them without harm.

sentences.zh: 有與同失者，則明飾其無失也。

translations.literal: Have those with same losses, then clearly adorn their no loss.
translations.idiomatic: If there are those with the same losses, then clearly adorn their no loss.

sentences.zh: 大忠無所拂悟，辭言無所擊排，迺後申其辯知焉。

translations.literal: Great loyalty has no opposing awakening, flowery words have no attacking repelling, only then extend his eloquence and wisdom.
translations.idiomatic: Great loyalty has no opposing awakening, flowery words have no attacking repelling—only then extend his eloquence and wisdom.

sentences.zh: 此所以親近不疑，知盡之難也。

translations.literal: This is why close and intimate without suspicion, thoroughly knowing the difficulty.
translations.idiomatic: This is why close and intimate without suspicion—thoroughly knowing the difficulty.

sentences.zh: 得曠日彌久，而周澤既渥，深計而不疑，交爭而不罪，迺明計利害以致其功，直指是非以飾其身，以此相持，此說之成也。

translations.literal: Obtain broad days increasingly long, and favor already abundant, deep plans without suspicion, contending without crime, only then clarify plan advantages and disadvantages to achieve its merit, directly point right and wrong to adorn his person, with this mutually holding, this is persuasion's success.
translations.idiomatic: Obtain broad days increasingly long, and favor already abundant, deep plans without suspicion, contending without crime—only then clarify plan advantages and disadvantages to achieve its merit, directly point right and wrong to adorn his person, with this mutually holding—this is persuasion's success.

translations.literal: The essentials of all persuasion lie in knowing to adorn what the persuaded respects, and extinguish what he finds ugly. He himself knows his plans, then do not press him with his losses; He himself braves his decisions, then do not anger him with his enemies; he himself boasts his strength, then do not overwhelm him with its difficulty. Plan different affairs with same plan, praise different people with same travelers, then adorn them without harm. Have those with same losses, then clearly adorn their no loss. Great loyalty has no opposing awakening, flowery words have no attacking repelling, only then extend his eloquence and wisdom. This is why close and intimate without suspicion, thoroughly knowing the difficulty. Obtain broad days increasingly long, and favor already abundant, deep plans without suspicion, contending without crime, only then clarify plan advantages and disadvantages to achieve its merit, directly point right and wrong to adorn his person, with this mutually holding, this is persuasion's success.

sentences.zh: 伊尹為庖，百里奚為虜，皆所由干其上也。

translations.literal: Yi Yin became cook, Bai Li Xi became captive, all the paths by which they petitioned their superiors.
translations.idiomatic: Yi Yin became a cook, Bai Li Xi became a captive—all the paths by which they petitioned their superiors.

sentences.zh: 故此二子者，皆聖人也，猶不能無役身而涉世如此其汙也，則非能仕之所設也。

translations.literal: Therefore these two sons, all sages, yet could not avoid debasing their persons and entering the world in such filth, then this is not what able service establishes.
translations.idiomatic: Therefore these two men, both sages, yet could not avoid debasing their persons and entering the world in such filth—then this is not what able service establishes.

translations.literal: Yi Yin became cook, Bai Li Xi became captive, all the paths by which they petitioned their superiors. Therefore these two sons, all sages, yet could not avoid debasing their persons and entering the world in such filth, then this is not what able service establishes.

sentences.zh: 宋有富人，天雨牆壞。

translations.literal: Song had a rich man, heaven rained wall collapsed.
translations.idiomatic: Song had a rich man. Heaven rained and the wall collapsed.

sentences.zh: 其子曰「不築且有盜」，其鄰人之父亦云，暮而果大亡其財，其家甚知其子而疑鄰人之父。

translations.literal: His son said 'not repair and moreover have thieves', his neighbor's father also said so, evening and indeed greatly lost their wealth, his family greatly trusted his son yet suspected the neighbor's father.
translations.idiomatic: His son said 'not repair and moreover there will be thieves.' His neighbor's father also said so. In the evening they indeed greatly lost their wealth. His family greatly trusted his son yet suspected the neighbor's father.

sentences.zh: 昔者鄭武公欲伐胡，迺以其子妻之。

translations.literal: In ancient times Zheng Wu Gong wished to attack Hu, thus married his son to them.
translations.idiomatic: In ancient times Zheng Wu Gong wished to attack Hu, thus he married his son to them.

sentences.zh: 因問群臣曰： 「吾欲用兵，誰可伐者？」

translations.literal: Then asked the ministers: 'I wish to use troops, who can be attacked?'
translations.idiomatic: Then he asked the ministers: 'I wish to use troops—who can be attacked?'

sentences.zh: 關其思曰：「胡可伐。」

translations.literal: Guan Qi Si said: 'Hu can be attacked.'
translations.idiomatic: Guan Qi Si said: 'Hu can be attacked.'

sentences.zh: 迺戮關其思，曰：「胡，兄弟之國也，子言伐之，何也？」

translations.literal: Thus executed Guan Qi Si, said: 'Hu is brother state, you speak of attacking it, why?'
translations.idiomatic: Thus he executed Guan Qi Si and said: 'Hu is a brother state. You speak of attacking it—why?'

sentences.zh: 胡君聞之，以鄭為親己而不備鄭。

translations.literal: Hu lord heard it, considered Zheng close to himself and did not prepare against Zheng.
translations.idiomatic: The Hu lord heard it and considered Zheng close to himself, thus did not prepare against Zheng.

sentences.zh: 鄭人襲胡，取之。

translations.literal: Zheng people attacked Hu, took it.
translations.idiomatic: The Zheng people attacked Hu and took it.

sentences.zh: 此二說者，其知皆當矣，然而甚者為戮，薄者見疑。

translations.literal: These two persuaders, their knowledge all appropriate, yet the severe one executed, the light one suspected.
translations.idiomatic: These two persuaders—their knowledge was all appropriate, yet the severe one was executed and the light one suspected.

sentences.zh: 非知之難也，處知則難矣。

translations.literal: Not that knowledge is difficult, but applying knowledge is difficult.
translations.idiomatic: Not that knowledge is difficult, but applying knowledge is difficult.

translations.literal: Song had a rich man, heaven rained wall collapsed. His son said 'not repair and moreover have thieves', his neighbor's father also said so, evening and indeed greatly lost their wealth, his family greatly trusted his son yet suspected the neighbor's father. In ancient times Zheng Wu Gong wished to attack Hu, thus married his son to them. Then asked the ministers: 'I wish to use troops, who can be attacked?' Guan Qi Si said: 'Hu can be attacked.' Thus executed Guan Qi Si, said: 'Hu is brother state, you speak of attacking it, why?' Hu lord heard it, considered Zheng close to himself and did not prepare against Zheng. Zheng people attacked Hu, took it. These two persuaders, their knowledge all appropriate, yet the severe one executed, the light one suspected. Not that knowledge is difficult, but applying knowledge is difficult.

sentences.zh: 昔者彌子瑕見愛於衛君。

translations.literal: In ancient times Mi Zi Xia was loved by Wei lord.
translations.idiomatic: In ancient times Mi Zi Xia was loved by the Wei lord.

sentences.zh: 衛國之法，竊駕君車者罪至刖。

translations.literal: Wei state's law, stealing the lord's carriage drivers punished by amputation.
translations.idiomatic: Wei state's law: those who steal and drive the lord's carriage are punished by amputation.

sentences.zh: 既而彌子之母病，人聞，往夜告之，彌子矯駕君車而出。

translations.literal: Soon Mi Zi's mother ill, people heard, went at night to inform him, Mi Zi falsely took the lord's carriage and went out.
translations.idiomatic: Soon Mi Zi's mother was ill. People heard and went at night to inform him. Mi Zi falsely took the lord's carriage and went out.

sentences.zh: 君聞之而賢之曰：「孝哉，為母之故而犯刖罪！」

translations.literal: Lord heard and considered him worthy saying: 'Filial indeed, for mother's sake violates amputation punishment!'
translations.idiomatic: The lord heard and considered him worthy, saying: 'Filial indeed—for his mother's sake he violates the amputation punishment!'

sentences.zh: 與君游果園，彌子食桃而甘，不盡而奉君。

translations.literal: With lord touring orchard, Mi Zi ate peach and sweet, not finished and presented to lord.
translations.idiomatic: With the lord touring the orchard, Mi Zi ate a peach and it was sweet. Not finished, he presented it to the lord.

sentences.zh: 君曰：「愛我哉，忘其口而念我！」

translations.literal: Lord said: 'Loves me indeed, forgets his mouth and thinks of me!'
translations.idiomatic: The lord said: 'Loves me indeed—forgets his own mouth and thinks of me!'

sentences.zh: 及彌子色衰而愛弛，得罪於君。

translations.literal: When Mi Zi appearance declined and love slackened, offended the lord.
translations.idiomatic: When Mi Zi's appearance declined and love slackened, he offended the lord.

sentences.zh: 君曰：「是嘗矯駕吾車，又嘗食我以其餘桃。」

translations.literal: Lord said: 'This once falsely took my carriage, also once fed me with his remaining peach.'
translations.idiomatic: The lord said: 'This one once falsely took my carriage, and also once fed me with his remaining peach.'

sentences.zh: 故彌子之行未變於初也，前見賢而後獲罪者，愛憎之至變也。

translations.literal: Therefore Mi Zi's conduct not changed from beginning, previously seen as worthy yet later obtained crime, love and hate's extreme change.
translations.idiomatic: Therefore Mi Zi's conduct had not changed from the beginning. Previously seen as worthy yet later obtained crime—this is love and hate's extreme change.

sentences.zh: 故有愛於主，則知當而加親；

translations.literal: Therefore have favor with lord, then knowledge appropriate and add closeness;
translations.idiomatic: Therefore if you have favor with the lord, then knowledge appropriate and add closeness;

sentences.zh: 見憎於主，則罪當而加疏。

translations.literal: seen as hated by lord, then crime appropriate and add distance.
translations.idiomatic: if seen as hated by the lord, then crime appropriate and add distance.

sentences.zh: 故諫說之士不可不察愛憎之主而後說之矣。

translations.literal: Therefore remonstrating persuaders cannot not examine the lord's loves and hates then persuade him.
translations.idiomatic: Therefore remonstrating persuaders cannot not examine the lord's loves and hates and then persuade him.

sentences.zh: 夫龍之為蟲也，可擾狎而騎也。

translations.literal: The dragon as an insect, can be disturbed and familiarly ridden.
translations.idiomatic: The dragon as an insect can be disturbed and familiarly ridden.

sentences.zh: 然其喉下有逆鱗徑尺，人有嬰之，則必殺人。

translations.literal: Yet its throat below has reverse scales one foot across, if a person touches them, then certainly kills the person.
translations.idiomatic: Yet below its throat it has reverse scales one foot across—if a person touches them, then it certainly kills the person.

sentences.zh: 人主亦有逆鱗，說之者能無嬰人主之逆鱗，則幾矣。

translations.literal: The ruler also has reverse scales, persuaders who can avoid touching the ruler's reverse scales, then nearly succeed.
translations.idiomatic: The ruler also has reverse scales—persuaders who can avoid touching the ruler's reverse scales then nearly succeed.

translations.literal: In ancient times Mi Zi Xia was loved by Wei lord. Wei state's law, stealing the lord's carriage drivers punished by amputation. Soon Mi Zi's mother ill, people heard, went at night to inform him, Mi Zi falsely took the lord's carriage and went out. Lord heard and considered him worthy saying: 'Filial indeed, for mother's sake violates amputation punishment!' With lord touring orchard, Mi Zi ate peach and sweet, not finished and presented to lord. Lord said: 'Loves me indeed, forgets his mouth and thinks of me!' When Mi Zi appearance declined and love slackened, offended the lord. Lord said: 'This once falsely took my carriage, also once fed me with his remaining peach.' Therefore Mi Zi's conduct not changed from beginning, previously seen as worthy yet later obtained crime, love and hate's extreme change. Therefore have favor with lord, then knowledge appropriate and add closeness; seen as hated by lord, then crime appropriate and add distance. Therefore remonstrating persuaders cannot not examine the lord's loves and hates then persuade him. The dragon as an insect, can be disturbed and familiarly ridden. Yet its throat below has reverse scales one foot across, if a person touches them, then certainly kills the person. The ruler also has reverse scales, persuaders who can avoid touching the ruler's reverse scales, then nearly succeed.

sentences.zh: 人或傳其書至秦。

translations.literal: Someone transmitted his book to Qin.
translations.idiomatic: Someone transmitted his book to Qin.

sentences.zh: 秦王見孤憤、五蠹之書，曰：「嗟乎，寡人得見此人與之游，死不恨矣！」

translations.literal: Qin king saw Lonely Indignation, Five Parasites book, said: 'Alas, I could see this person and travel with him, die without regret!'
translations.idiomatic: The Qin king saw the book 'Lonely Indignation, Five Parasites' and said: 'Alas, if I could see this person and travel with him, I would die without regret!'

sentences.zh: 李斯曰：「此韓非之所著書也。」

translations.literal: Li Si said: 'This is Han Fei's written book.'
translations.idiomatic: Li Si said: 'This is Han Fei's written book.'

sentences.zh: 秦因急攻韓。

translations.literal: Qin thus urgently attacked Han.
translations.idiomatic: Qin thus urgently attacked Han.

sentences.zh: 韓王始不用非，及急，乃遣非使秦。

translations.literal: Han king initially did not use Fei, when urgent, then sent Fei as envoy to Qin.
translations.idiomatic: The Han king initially did not use Fei, but when urgent, then sent Fei as envoy to Qin.

sentences.zh: 秦王悅之，未信用。

translations.literal: Qin king pleased with him, not yet employed.
translations.idiomatic: The Qin king was pleased with him but not yet employed him.

sentences.zh: 李斯、姚賈害之，毀之曰：「韓非，韓之諸公子也。

translations.literal: Li Si, Yao Jia harmed him, slandered saying: 'Han Fei is Han's various princes.
translations.idiomatic: Li Si and Yao Jia harmed him and slandered him, saying: 'Han Fei is Han's various princes.

sentences.zh: 今王欲并諸侯，非終為韓不為秦，此人之情也。

translations.literal: Now king wishes to annex the feudal lords, Fei ultimately for Han not for Qin, this is human feeling.
translations.idiomatic: Now the king wishes to annex the feudal lords—Fei will ultimately be for Han not for Qin. This is human feeling.'

sentences.zh: 今王不用，久留而歸之，此自遺患也，不如以過法誅之。」

translations.literal: Now king does not employ, long detain and return him, this leaves disaster for oneself, not as good as executing by false law.'
translations.idiomatic: Now the king does not employ him—long detain and return him, this leaves disaster for oneself. Not as good as executing him by false law.''

sentences.zh: 秦王以為然，下吏治非。

translations.literal: Qin king considered it so, sent officials to treat Fei.
translations.idiomatic: The Qin king considered it so and sent officials to deal with Fei.

sentences.zh: 李斯使人遺非藥，使自殺。

translations.literal: Li Si sent men to give Fei medicine, made him commit suicide.
translations.idiomatic: Li Si sent men to give Fei medicine and made him commit suicide.

sentences.zh: 韓非欲自陳，不得見。

translations.literal: Han Fei wished to explain himself, could not be seen.
translations.idiomatic: Han Fei wished to explain himself but could not be seen.

sentences.zh: 秦王後悔之，使人赦之，非已死矣。

translations.literal: Qin king later regretted it, sent men to pardon him, Fei already dead.
translations.idiomatic: The Qin king later regretted it and sent men to pardon him, but Fei was already dead.

sentences.zh: 申子、韓子皆著書，傳於後世，學者多有。

translations.literal: Shen Zi, Han Zi both wrote books, transmitted to later generations, scholars have many.
translations.idiomatic: Shen Zi and Han Zi both wrote books that were transmitted to later generations—scholars have many of them.

sentences.zh: 余獨悲韓子為說難而不能自脫耳。

translations.literal: I alone pity Han Zi wrote Difficulty of Persuasion yet could not save himself.
translations.idiomatic: I alone pity Han Zi for writing 'Difficulty of Persuasion' yet could not save himself.

translations.literal: Someone transmitted his book to Qin. Qin king saw Lonely Indignation, Five Parasites book, said: 'Alas, I could see this person and travel with him, die without regret!' Li Si said: 'This is Han Fei's written book.' Qin thus urgently attacked Han. Han king initially did not use Fei, when urgent, then sent Fei as envoy to Qin. Qin king pleased with him, not yet employed. Li Si, Yao Jia harmed him, slandered saying: 'Han Fei is Han's various princes. Now king wishes to annex the feudal lords, Fei ultimately for Han not for Qin, this is human feeling. Now king does not employ, long detain and return him, this leaves disaster for oneself, not as good as executing by false law.' Qin king considered it so, sent officials to treat Fei. Li Si sent men to give Fei medicine, made him commit suicide. Han Fei wished to explain himself, could not be seen. Qin king later regretted it, sent men to pardon him, Fei already dead. Shen Zi, Han Zi both wrote books, transmitted to later generations, scholars have many. I alone pity Han Zi wrote Difficulty of Persuasion yet could not save himself.

sentences.zh: 太史公曰：老子所貴道，虛無，因應變化於無為，故著書辭稱微妙難識。

translations.literal: The Grand Historian says: Laozi valued the Dao, emptiness nothingness, responding to changes at non-action, therefore his book words speak of subtle mystery difficult to recognize.
translations.idiomatic: The Grand Historian says: Laozi valued the Dao—emptiness and nothingness, responding to changes at non-action. Therefore his book's words speak of subtle mystery difficult to recognize.

sentences.zh: 莊子散道德，放論，要亦歸之自然。

translations.literal: Zhuangzi scattered morality and virtue, unrestrained discussions, in essentials also return to naturalness.
translations.idiomatic: Zhuangzi scattered morality and virtue with unrestrained discussions, but in essentials also returned to naturalness.

sentences.zh: 申子卑卑，施之於名實。

translations.literal: Shen Zi lowly and humble, applied to name and reality.
translations.idiomatic: Shen Zi was lowly and humble, applying himself to name and reality.

sentences.zh: 韓子引繩墨，切事情，明是非，其極慘礉少恩。

translations.literal: Han Zi drew ink lines, cut affairs, clarified right and wrong, his extreme harsh cruel lacking mercy.
translations.idiomatic: Han Zi drew ink lines and plumb lines, cut affairs, clarified right and wrong—his extreme was harsh and cruel, lacking mercy.

sentences.zh: 皆原於道德之意，而老子深遠矣。

translations.literal: All originated from morality and virtue's intent, yet Laozi profound and far-reaching.
translations.idiomatic: All originated from the intent of the Way and virtue, yet Laozi was profound and far-reaching.

translations.literal: The Grand Historian says: Laozi valued the Dao, emptiness nothingness, responding to changes at non-action, therefore his book words speak of subtle mystery difficult to recognize. Zhuangzi scattered morality and virtue, unrestrained discussions, in essentials also return to naturalness. Shen Zi lowly and humble, applied to name and reality. Han Zi drew ink lines, cut affairs, clarified right and wrong, his extreme harsh cruel lacking mercy. All originated from morality and virtue's intent, yet Laozi profound and far-reaching.
